head.headtext: Hearsay rule; admission and exclusion of hearsay

para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-802 states, “Hearsay shall not be admissible except as provided by this article; provided, however, that if a party does not properly object to hearsay, the objection shall be deemed waived, and the hearsay evidence shall be legal evidence and admissible.”

A party alleging error carries the burden of showing it affirmatively by the record, and when the burden is not met, the judgment is assumed correct and will be affirmed. As a result, a party's failure to object to an exhibit containing hearsay constitutes a waiver of the error, such that the evidence shall be considered legal and admissible.[1]

Note, however, that O.C.G.A. § 24-1-103(d) provides that nothing shall prohibit an appellate court from taking notice of plain errors affecting substantial rights of a party even if no objection is made at trial.[2] To demonstrate plain error, a party must show (1) that the party did not affirmatively waive the error; (2) that the error was clear and no open to reasonable dispute; (3) that the error affected substantial rights of the party; and (4) that the error seriously affected the fairness of the judicial proceeding.[3]

Hearsay evidence is not admissible to prove the truth of the fact asserted unless it falls under one or more of the recognized exceptions to the general rule excluding hearsay. There are many exceptions to the hearsay rule. Some of them concern evidence that was admissible long before there was a rule excluding hearsay, such as a dying declaration, and have continued to be admitted as exceptions to the rule. Some matters, such as testimony given at a previous trial, are considered hearsay under specific definitions, rather than hearsay falling under an exception.
Hearsay may be considered in juvenile cases since the Rules of Evidence do not apply.[4]

Mashburn Construction, L.P. v. CharterBank, 340 Ga. App. 580, 798 S.E.2d 251 (2017); Oduok v. State, 347 Ga. App. 178, 817 S.E.2d 145 (2018). Before the current Code became effective, hearsay had no probative value, even if no objection was raised. Under the new Code, the objection may be waived. In Interest of H. B., 346 Ga. App. 163, 816 S.E.2d 313 (2018); Doe v. State, 347 Ga. App. 246, 819 S.E.2d 58 (2018).
Mosley v. State, 298 Ga. 849, 785 S.E.2d 297 (2016); Harvey v. State, 300 Ga. 598, 797 S.E.2d 75 (2017) (overruled on other grounds by, Nalls v. State, 304 Ga. 168, 815 S.E.2d 38 (2018)).
See Mosley v. State, 298 Ga. 849, 785 S.E.2d 297 (2016), citing Gates v. State, 298 Ga. 324, 327(3), 781 S.E.2d 772 (2016); Wilson v. State, 301 Ga. 83, 799 S.E.2d 757 (2017).
